name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: A better funded IRS is a win for our country: fewer audits for you, more money to ensure that everyone plays by the same rules, and billions of dollars to reduce the deficit. It‚Äôs one more way that the Democrats' new law is a win for Delaware.

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: FACT: Roughly half the new IRS funds will be spent on operations, tech modernization, and taxpayer services. Why? Because Americans expect them to be better at reducing backlogs, paying refunds, and correctly dispatching auditors.

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: FACT: The IRS is not planning on hiring ‚Äú87,000 new auditors.‚Äù What is true? The IRS has lost a third of its employees since 2010. Hiring more staff is intended to fill that gap and create a more efficient team that should be more responsive to taxpayers‚Äô concerns.

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: FACT: New audits will focus on high-end tax evasion: big corporations and the wealthiest Americans who use loopholes and armies of accountants to avoid paying their fair share.

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: FACT: The Trump-appointed IRS Commissioner has said that families under that threshold are LESS likely to be audited‚Äî‚Äòbetter technology and customer service would also make it less likely that compliant taxpayers would be audited.'

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text: FACT: The @USTreasury ‚Äì including the Trump-appointed IRS Commissioner ‚Äì has made clear that new funding should not increase audit rates on families earning under $400K each year.

name: Senator Chris Coons
tweet_text:
I‚Äôve heard from Delawareans concerned about new IRS funding in the Inflation Reduction Act. Here‚Äôs the truth: for families earning under $400K and small businesses, the chances of getting audited shouldn't increase. You may even get your refund faster.
 
Let's lay out some facts:

tweet_text: Before COVID-19 hit, affordable and fair housing was already a problem. Nearly 11 million households paid more than half of their incomes towards housing and Black and LatinX homeownership rates were 30 percent lower than those of white families.
